title: What are the most popular spices in Brazil? - Quora

response.answer_text: That's not a very accurately worded question. You see Brazil is a massive country. Its a melting pot of cultures and depending on what area of Brazil you are referring to will greatly change which spices are used. For example, in the northern part of Brazil, spefically in the northwest where the amazon is, there are over 100 different species of peppers that are harvested. Now, you go northeast and you are in to regions of heavy African influence, so strong chilis are used along with palm oil and coconut milk. Head south into Sao Paolo and the spice level is very tame. Lots of garlic and onions are used. And meat is essentially on everyone's table. Beef is a way of life down there and the spice they use on it is rock salt. That's it.. They pack on rock salt as it kisses the eucalyptus charcoal fire and as they turn the meat the salt slowly falls off and the remnants are left on the perfectly grilled pieces of delicious picanha. In the US picanha is what's called the cap steak, it's the very top of a top sirloin butt primal cut. This cut of beef is the most popular cut in Brazil and it's delicious.. Head even farther south and you'll hit Rio Grande do Sol, this area was heavily influenced by German immigrants after world war 2 and some areas feel like youre walking down the streets of some small villages in Germany. The architecture is very similar and as you might of guessed the food is heavily influenced as well. Mustard sauces, schnitzel, braised pork shins.. mmm mmm mmm..

Apart from specific parts of the country, specially the state of Bahia, Brazilian food is not particularly “hot” spicy. Many spices are used though, and there’s a lot of regional variation. The most common seasonings used throughout the country are probably garlic and onions/scallions alongside small quantities of black pepper. Apart from that, in the North and Northeast cilantro is very common, while in the South and Southeast parsley is used more often.  Bahian Vatapá, with cilantro and a red pepper Rice and beans are the main staples in Brazil and people usually cook beans with bay leaves and sometimes cumin, or a combination of cumin and black peppers.  In the Center-West region and parts of the state of Minas Gerais, the pequi is a very common seasoning, specially in rice and chicken dishes. It’s a interesting fruit with a very distinct flavor and a rare example of a fruit used as a spice.  Some people eat the whole fruit, but you have to be careful because it’s full of thorns hidden under its pulp that can hurt your mouth if you just bite it as you’d normally bite a fruit.  Chicken with pequi.
